rituals_practices.definition: Rituals and practices in Sanatana Dharma are spiritual and cultural activities performed to maintain harmony with cosmic order and express devotion.

origin.purpose: To connect the individual with the divine and uphold Dharma.

daily_practices: Lighting a lamp (Deepa) at home altar

common_rituals: Archana – Chanting names of the deity and offering flowers.
Abhishekam – Ritual bathing of the deity with water, milk, honey, and ghee.
Aarti – Waving of lamps before the deity accompanied by devotional songs.
Naivedyam – Offering food to the deity, later distributed as Prasadam.
Darshan – Viewing the deity with reverence and devotion.
Homa – Fire ritual performed in temple premises for purification and blessings.

south_india: Panchamrita Abhishekam – Bathing deity with five sacred substances (milk, curd, ghee, honey, sugar).
Vahana Seva – Deity taken on a procession on different mounts during festivals.
Deepa Aradhana – Elaborate lamp worship in temples like Meenakshi and Tirupati.
north_india: Bhajan and Kirtan – Devotional singing in temple halls.
Jalabhishek – Offering water to Shiva Lingam, especially during Shravan month.
Rath Yatra – Chariot procession of deities during major festivals.
east_india: Durga Puja rituals – Elaborate worship of Goddess Durga with artistic idols.
Chandi Path – Recitation of Devi Mahatmya during Navaratri.
Sandhi Puja – Special offering during the transition of Ashtami and Navami.
west_india: Garba and Dandiya – Dance rituals during Navaratri in Gujarat.
Tulsi Vivah – Symbolic marriage of Tulsi plant with Lord Vishnu.
Abhanga singing – Devotional songs in Varkari tradition of Maharashtra.

symbolism: Aarti represents removal of darkness and welcoming divine light.
Prasadam symbolizes grace and blessings of the deity.

modern_relevance.mindfulness: Daily rituals promote mental peace and discipline.

key_scriptural_references.quote_summary: Rituals maintain cosmic order and harmony.
Perform actions as an offering to the divine.
